Aru hito ga koko e kimashita.
Yokohama to iu tokoro o shitte imasu ka.
Chichi wa Tōkyō ni sunde imasu.
Toshokan ni iku to, Maiku-san ni aimashita.
1. What kind of person do you think Urashima Taro is? Describe him as well as you can.
2. If you were Urashima Taro, would you stay in the Dragon Palace forever?
3. Have you ever had an experience of revisiting some place, only to fi nd it completely diff erent than you remembered?
that appears on snowy nights. Th e legend appears to have come into being during the
Muromachi period (1336–1573). It is mentioned in the
Moshi ha- nashitara, omae-san no inochi wa nai yo
Aru toki shiranai hito ga uchi ni kimashita.
A stranger came to my house one day.
Benten to iu resutoran o shitte imasu ka.
Do you know the restaurant called Benten?
Sūpā ni banana o kai ni ikimashi- ta.
I went to a supermarket to buy bananas.
Uchi ni kaeru to, denki ga tsuite imashita.
Kukkī o takusan tabete shimai- mashita.
I have eaten a lot of cookies (and I regret it).
Sūgaku o senkō suru koto ni shimashita.
I decided to major in mathematics.
Ashita wa tesuto ga aru node, kyō wa benkyō shimasu.
I have a test tomorrow, so I will study today.
Mado o akeppanashi ni shinaide kudasai.
Please don’t leave the window open.
Nigeyō to shimashita ga, nige-raremasen deshita.
Moshi ame ga futtara, eiga o mimasu.
I’m in the middle of eating now.
1. Why do you think the Snow Woman chose not to kill Minokichi?
2. Why do you think the Snow Woman left  her children behind?
3. Have you ever heard of or read any other scary stories related to snow?
Ryūnosuke Akutagawa was born in 1892 in Tokyo. His mother developed a mental illness shortly aft er he was born, and he was adopted and raised by his
maternal aunt and her husband. Akutagawa was sickly and hypersensitive as a boy. He studied English literature at the Tokyo Imperial University (currently
the University of Tokyo) and taught English for a short time aft er graduation.
He admired and was mentored by Sōseki Natsume. He got married to Fumi Tsukamoto in 1918 and they had three children. Akutagawa committed suicide
1. It is diffi  cult to express the same level of politeness toward Buddha in English due to the lack of honorifi c expressions that correspond to the
2. Specifi c terms from Buddhism such as
Yōko-san wa tenshi no yō ni yasa- shii hito desu.
Yoko is a person who is kind just like an angel.
Otōto ni hon o yonde agemashita.
1. Find some background information about Akutagawa Ryūnosuke and discuss it.
2. Have you ever seen lotuses? How are lotuses described in this story?
3. Why did Buddha lower the spider’s thread?
Terebi o mi-nagara asa-gohan o tabemashita.
Kafeteria ni iku to, Tanaka-san ga matteimashita.
1. How is Hell described in this story?
2. What kind of images did you have about Hell before reading this story?
3. How is the spider’s thread described in this story? Can it metaphorically symbolize something in our world?
Tanaka-san ga kitara, watashi wa kaerimasu.
Tanaka-san wa kyonen Shinga- pōru ni itta to itteimashita.
lit., even without a moment to say “Ah”
1. What do you think Kandata was thinking when he saw so many sinners climbing up the thread?
2. How do you feel about Kandata telling the other sinners to get off ? Are there people who are like him in our society?
3. Why do you think the spider’s thread broke right aft er Kandata asked the other sinners to get off ?
a car that is about to break down
2. What kind of lessons do you think this story teaches us? List as many as you can.
Takeo Arishima was born in 1878 in Tokyo, the son of a high ranking offi  - cial in the Finance Ministry of Japan. He studied at Sapporo Agricultural Col-
lege, Haverford College, and Harvard University. He was once a Christian, but gradually drift ed to socialism. Arishima got married to Yasuko Kamio in 1910
and they had three children. However, Yasuko died of tuberculosis in 1916.
Arishima later had an aff air with a married woman, Akiko Hatano, who was an editor for a literary magazine. Th ey committed suicide together in 1923.
2. Th ere is no perfect English equivalent for
3. Th ere is no explicit linguistic clue that shows the gender of M in the Japanese text. However, we assumed that M is a male and used the male
Mada natsu na no ni suzushii desu.
Once you push it, it opens.
Tanaka-san wa saikin yoku shaberu yō ni narimashita.
Mr. Tanaka started to talk more these days.
Ittai nani ga okitan desu ka.
Igirisu ni iku koto ni shimashita.
I decided to go to England.
Ashita wa tesuto ga aru no de, kyō wa benkyō shimasu.
Mō aki na no de suzushii desu.
Because it is already autumn, it’s cool.
1. Find some background information about Arishima Takeo and discuss it.
3. Why did the protagonist’s grandmother discourage them from swim- ming on that day? Why did they persist in doing so?
Tenshi no yō na hito desu.
E ni kaita yō na mochi desu ne.
Monku o iinagara mo tasukete- kureta.
(He) went out, leaving the door open.
Kutsu no mama uchi ni hairi- mashita.
I entered my house with my shoes on.
2. What kind of games did they play in the ocean? Have you played similar games?
Anata no kimochi wa te ni toru yō ni wakarimasu.
I understood your feeling very clearly.
Kinō kono hon o yomihajime mashita.
I started to read this book.
Uso o tsukō to shimashita ga tsukemasen deshita.
1. Do you think M’s warning was helpful? Why?
2. If you suddenly realized that your feet could not reach the fl oor of the ocean, what would you do?
Ano mise ni iku tanbi ni ichi- man-en tsukatte shimaimasu.
1. Compare your swimming skills with that of the characters in this story.
2. Describe the emotions of the protagonist, being placed between M and his sister right in the ocean.
3. What kind of person did the protagonist think he was on this day?
wakai otoko wa watashi no sasu hō o misadamete-imashita ga, yagate ...
1. How do you think the protagonist felt when he saw no one on the shore?
2. How do you think the protagonist felt when M brought a young man?
3. How do you think the protagonist felt when the young man started to swim toward his little sister?
1. How do you think the young man’s swimming appeared to the protago- nist?
2. What sort of diff erent metaphors can you think of for describing the young man’s swimming?
1. Why do you think the protagonist felt a little better when he realized that his sister was running toward their grandmother?
2. How do you think the protagonist felt when he was standing next to the young man? Why?
Th e light has been turned on.
a dress that looks expen- sive
Marude kumo no ue o aruiteiru yō datta.
It was just like walking on a cloud.
Ano kuruma o kau tsumori desu.
ki o tsukete okure de nai to
1. What kind of person was the young man? Why do you think this?
2. Do you think the relationship between the protagonist and his sister changed aft er that day?
3. What kind of lessons do you think this story can teach us? List as many as you can.
Kenji Miyazawa was born in 1896 in Iwate in northern Japan, to a wealthy family that ran a pawnshop. As a devout Buddhist, he refused to take over his
family business and dedicated his life to helping the poor. He studied Agricul- tural Science at Morioka Agriculture and Forestry College. He was also an art-
ist (painter, cellist and composer), loved opera and classical music, and studied English, German and Esperanto. He died of pneumonia in 1933.
was pub- lished in 1934, one year aft er his death.
me o sara no yō ni suru
Terebi o minagara ban-gohan o tabemashita.
1. Find out more about Miyazawa Kenji’s background, and share with your friends/classmates.
2. Do you think this story took place in Japan?  Why or why not?
3. Do you play any musical instruments?  Describe your experience.
Ano hito wa kowasō desu ne.
Kuma ga kita node shindeiru furi o shimashita.
Because a bear came, I pretended to be dead.
1. Why did everyone look at their music or pluck their instruments “on pur- pose” when Gauche was
2. What kind of person do you think the conductor is? Why does he get angry so oft en?
3. How do you think Gauche felt aft er the rehearsal?
Hon o tēburu no ue ni okimashita
I put my book on the table.
1. What do you think of the environment of Gauche’s home?
2. How do you think Gauche felt when he started practicing his cello at home?
3. What did the cat do that made Gauche upset?
Go-ji ni benkyō o shihajime- mashita.
Neyō to shimashita ga nerare- masen deshita.
2. Why do you think Gauche closed the door and the windows?
3. Do you think Gauche played “Tiger Hunting in India” well? Why?
4. How do you think Gauche felt aft er the cat left ?
Ani wa gitā o hikinagara utaimasu.
1. Have you ever heard cuckoos sing? How did you feel?
2. Have you practiced the scales while singing or playing string instru- ments? How did you do it? How was the experience?
Ima, Nihon-en wa takaiyō desu ne.
It appears that Japanese yen is ex- pensive now.
1. What did Gauche notice as he played the cello along with the bird’s singing?
2. How does the author describe the scene where the bird hit the glass many times while Gauche struggled to help it? How did it make you feel?
3. How do you think Gauche felt aft er the bird left ?
Dare ga nan to itte mo kesshin wa kawarimasen.
No matter who says what, my decision will not change.
1. Why did Gauche almost burst out laughing?
2. Did Gauche fi nd a problem as he played with the baby raccoon? Did he fi nd a solution for it? Did he do something aft er that?
2. Th ere is no clue about the gender of the baby mouse in the original Jap- anese text. However, we took the liberty of using the masculine pro-
Nihon de hatarakitai nara, Nihon-go o benkyō-shita hō ga ii
If you want to work in Japan, it is better to study Japanese.
Kore o nomeba, sukkiri shimasu yo.
Watashi no iukoto o kikeba yokattan desu.
1. Have you ever heard that music is good for our body and brain?
2. How do you think Gauche felt when he heard what the mother mouse said about the eff ect of his cello performance?
3. Who took care of you or took you to the hospital when you were sick dur- ing your childhood? What kind of things did he/she do for you? Talk
Hon o tēburu no ue ni okimashita.
1. What do you think of the relationship between the mother mouse and the baby mouse?
2. Why do you think Gauche gave a piece of bread to the mice?
3. Th e baby mouse went inside the cello through a hole. What kind of hole do you think it was?
Sensō ga owatte heishi ga jibun no kuni ni hikiagetekita.
Th e war ended and the soldiers came back to their homeland.
1. Why did Gauche decide to play “Tiger Hunting in India”? What was he thinking while he was playing this piece?
2. How do you think each animal helped Gauche to improve his cello skills?
3. Why do you think Gauche thought of the cuckoo?
4. Did your image of the conductor change aft er reading this section?
5. What kind of messages do you think this story gives us? List as many as you can.
ABOUT TUTTLE “Books to Span the East and West”
